facts.text: This is Civil Appeal No. 31 of 1965.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 31 of 1965.

facts.text: Appeal is by special leave from the judgment and order dated October 16, 1962 of the Bombay High Court in Special Civil Application No. 65 of 1962.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated October 16, 1962 of the Bombay High Court in Special Civil Application No. 65 of 1962.

facts.text: The appellants are the landlords and respondent No. 1 is the tenant.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants are the landlords and respondent I the tenant

facts.text: Tenancy pertains to Survey Nos. 15.17/2, 1500/2 and 1500/4 in village Nangalwedha, District Sholapur.

anchor.surface_text: in respect of Survey Nos. 15.17/2, 1500/2 and 1500/4 situate in village Nangalwedha, District Sholapur.

facts.text: Agreed rent under the tenancy was Rs. 95 per year.

anchor.surface_text: Under the tenancy the agreed rent was Rs. 95 per year.

facts.text: Tenant made default in paying the rent.

anchor.surface_text: As the tenant made default in paying the rent

facts.text: Appellants served tenant with a notice terminating the tenancy.

anchor.surface_text: the appellants served him with a numberice terminating the tenancy.

facts.text: On March 12, 1957, appellants filed application under section 29 of Bombay Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act LXVII of 1948 before Mamlatdar for eviction and possession.

anchor.surface_text: On March 12, 1957 they filed an application under section 29 of the Bombay Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act LXVII of 1948 before the Mamlatdar for eviction and possession

facts.text: Application for eviction on ground tenant failed to pay rent on due dates March 20th of each years 1951-52 to 1954-55, entitling to ejectment under section 25(2).

anchor.surface_text: on the ground that the tenant had failed to pay rent on the due dates, that is, March the 20th of each of the years 1951-52 to 1954-55 and that therefore they were entitled to an order of ejectment under section 25 2  of the Act.

facts.text: Applicable Act is LXVII of 1948 before amendment in 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The Act applicable to the said application is Act LXVII of 1948 before its amendment in 1956,

facts.text: For 1951-52, landlords filed suit for rent recovery; tenant paid Rs. 142 after appeal disposed on June 8, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: for the year 1951-52 the landlords had filed a suit for recovery of the rent and the tenant had paid Rs. 142 after his appeal against the decree passed against him was disposed of on June 8, 1956.

facts.text: Rs. 142 comprised Rs. 95 for 1951-52 and Rs. 47/8/- half rent for 1952-53.

anchor.surface_text: The amount of Rs. 142 companyprised of Rs. 95 for 1951-52 and Rs. 47/8/- being half the rent for 1952-53.

facts.text: For 1952-53, half rent paid in April 1956.

anchor.surface_text: For the year 1952-53 half of the amount of rent due from him was paid in April 1956.

facts.text: For 1953-54, landlords filed suit and tenant paid rent on May 5, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: For the year 1953-54 the landlords filed an assistance suit and the tenant paid the rent on May 5, 1955.

facts.text: For 1954-55, tenant paid and landlord received rent on April 12, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: For the year 1954-55 the tenant paid and the landlord received the rent on April 12, 1955.

facts.text: Mamlatdar dismissed appellants' application as tenant had paid up rent due and no arrears at date of institution.

anchor.surface_text: The Mamlatdar dismissed the appellants application on the ground, that the tenant having paid up the rent due by him and there being numberarrears at the date of the institution of the application the appellants were, number entitled to an- order of ejectment.

facts.text: District Deputy Collector dismissed appeal holding defaults not wilful as rents accepted before institution, discretion not to evict.

anchor.surface_text: In the appeal filed by the appellants before the District Deputy Collector, it was held that though the, tenant had failed to pay the rent on the due date, the- appellants. having admittedly accepted all the rents due to them before the, institution of their application the defaulter were number wilful and the Deputy Collector had therefore the discretion number to order eviction.

facts.text: Revenue Tribunal dismissed the appeal on the same ground.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal dismissed the appeal on the same ground.

facts.text: Appellants filed Special Civil Application in Bombay High Court under Art. 227 challenging Tribunal's order.

anchor.surface_text: Having failed before the Revenue Authorities the appellants filed a Special Civil Application in the High Court under Art. 227 of the Constitution challenging the companyrectness of the Tribunals order.

facts.text: High Court dismissed the application as admitted that landlords received all rent due and no arrears at date of application.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court dismissed the application observing that as it was an admitted position that the landlords had received all the rent due by the tenant and there were numberarrears due by him at the date of the said application. there was numberground for interfering with the Tribunals order.

facts.text: It is an admitted position that landlords had received all rent due by tenant and no arrears at date of application.

anchor.surface_text: as it was an admitted position that the landlords had received all the rent due by the tenant and there were numberarrears due by him at the date of the said application.

facts.text: Appellants obtained special leave from Supreme Court against High Court order.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants obtained special leave from this Court against the High Courts order and. that is how this appeal has companye up before us.
under Art. 227 of the Constitution challenging the correctness of the Tribunals order.
Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated October 16, 1962 of the Bombay High Court
The appellants obtained special leave from this Court against the High Courts order and. that is how this appeal has come up before us.

issues.text: Whether under s. 25(2) of the Act once the tenant made three defaults in payment of rent on the due dates, the landlord became entitled to terminate the tenancy and to an order of eviction against him even if the tenant had paid up the rent and the landlord had accepted it before the filing of the application

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the appellants contended that the High Court was in error in refusing to set aside the Tribunals order, that under s. 25 2  of the Act once the tenant made three defaults in payment of rent on the due dates, the landlord became entitled to terminate the tenancy and to an order of eviction against him, that there would be no question of the defaults being wilful or otherwise,

issues.text: Whether sub-section (2) of section 25 pre-supposes that the tenant was in arrears at the date of the application for eviction

anchor.surface_text: Sub-section  2  therefore also pre-supposes  i  that the tenant has made defaults for more than two years and  ii  that the tenant was in arrears at the date of the application which arrears in this case the Mamlatdar cannot order the tenant to pay up.

issues.text: Whether the Act rules out payment by the tenant and acceptance by the landlord of arrears of rent before institution of eviction proceedings resulting in waiver of termination of tenancy

anchor.surface_text: The Act therefore does not rule out the payment by the tenant and acceptance by the landlord of arrears of rent before a suit for eviction is instituted resulting in waiver by the landlord of the termination of tenancy by him.

issues.text: Whether the decision in Raja Ram Mahadev Pranjpe v. Aba Maruti Mali applies to a case where there were no arrears at the date of the application for ejectment

anchor.surface_text: In Raja Ram Mahadev Pranjypes Case 1  this Court, no doubt, held that on default in payment of rest for three years a statutory right accrued to a landlord under s. 25 2  to terminate the tenancy and to obtain possession, that the Act contained no provision for granting relief against forfeiture in such a case

issues.text: Whether relief under s. 114 of the Transfer of Property Act is available or inconsistent with the provisions of the Bombay Tenancy Act by reason of s.3

anchor.surface_text: relief under s. 114 of the Transfer of Property Act also would not be available as that section was inconsistent with the provisions of the Act and was, therefore, inapplicable by reason of section 3 of the Act

arguments.claim: s.25(1) allows Mamlatdar to order payment of arrears within 15 days and restore tenancy if complied; presupposes arrears at application

anchor.surface_text: By its sub-section 1 the section provides that where any tenancy held by a tenant is terminated for non-payment of rent and the landlord files any proceeding to eject the tenant, the Mamlatdar has to call upon the tenant to tender to the landlord the rent in arrears

arguments.claim: s.25(2) excludes s.25(1); applies to persistent default for three years; Mamlatdar cannot order payment or restore tenancy; presupposes arrears at application date

anchor.surface_text: Sub-section 2 provides that sub-section 1 shall not apply to a tenant whose tenancy is terminated for non-payment of rent if he has failed for any three years to pay rent within the period specified in s. 14. ... Sub-section 2 therefore also pre-supposes i that the tenant has made defaults for more than two years and ii that the tenant was in arrears at the date of the application

arguments.claim: Petitioner's construction leads to astonishing result: eviction right even after acceptance of arrears, contrary to landlord-tenant principles

anchor.surface_text: If this was not the correct construction of sub-section 2 and if the appellants construction were to be accepted it would lead to a very astonishing result, viz., that even where the tenant has paid up all the arrears and the landlord has accepted them, he would still have the right to evict the tenant,

arguments.claim: s.30 preserves tenant rights under usage/law/contract; Act does not rule out payment and acceptance of arrears before eviction resulting in waiver of termination

anchor.surface_text: The legislature on the contrary has been careful to provide expressly by section 30 of the Act that except as otherwise provided in s. 6 3 and s. 27 1 with which we are not concerned no other provision contained in the Act shall be construed to limit or abridge the rights or privileges of any tenant

arguments.claim: Raja Ram case held statutory right under s.25(2) with no relief against forfeiture; but did not address no-arrears scenario; rested on arrears existing at filing

anchor.surface_text: In Raja Ram Mahadev Pranjypes Case 1 this Court, no doubt, held that on default in payment of rest for three years a statutory right accrued to a landlord under s. 25 2 to terminate the tenancy and to obtain possession, that the Act contained no provision for granting relief against forfeiture in such a case

arguments.claim: No relief under TPA s.114 as inconsistent with Act per s.3; but inapplicable here anyway

anchor.surface_text: It also held that relief under s. 114 of the Transfer of Property Act also would not be available as that section was inconsistent with the provisions of the Act and was, therefore, inapplicable by reason of section 3 of the Act

holdings.text: Sub-section 2 therefore also pre-supposes (i) that the tenant has made defaults for more than two years and (ii) that the tenant was in arrears at the date of the application which arrears in this case the Mamlatdar cannot order the tenant to pay up.

anchor.surface_text: Sub-section  2  therefore also pre-supposes  i  that the tenant has made defaults for more than two years and  ii  that the tenant was in arrears at the date of the application which arrears in this case the Mamlatdar cannot order the tenant to pay up.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.25(2) excludes s.25(1) relief only where persistent defaults and arrears exist at filing; contrasts with s.25(1) which allows payment and restoration if arrears present.

holdings.text: The Act therefore does not rule out the payment by the tenant and acceptance by the landlord of arrears of rent before a suit for eviction is instituted resulting in waiver by the landlord of the termination of tenancy by him.

anchor.surface_text: The legislature on the companytrary has been careful to provide expressly by section 30 of the Act that except as otherwise provided in s. 6 3  and s. 27 1   with which we are number companycerned  numberother provision companytained in the Act shall be companystrued to limit or abridge the rights or privileges of any tenant under any usage or law for the time being in force or arising out of any companytract, grant, decree or order of a companyrt or otherwise howsoever. The Act therefore does not rule out the payment by the tenant and acceptance by the landlord of arrears of rent before a suit for eviction is instituted resulting in waiver by the landlord of the termination of tenancy by him.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.30 preserves tenant rights under law/usage/contract; acceptance of arrears waives termination as no statutory bar.

holdings.text: If the appellants construction were to be accepted it would lead to a very astonishing result, viz., that even where the tenant has paid up all the arrears and the landlord has accepted them, he would still have the right to evict the tenant.

anchor.surface_text: Sub-section  2  is in companytra-distinction of sub-section  1 , that is to say, where.as in the case of less than 3 defaults the Mamlatdar can call upon the tenant to pay the arrears and can on payment of such arrears direct that the tenancy was number terminated, he cannot do so under sub- section  2  where there are more than two defaults and direct that the tenancy had number been terminated. If this was number the companyrect companystruction of sub-section  2  and if the appellants companystruction were to be accepted it would lead to a very astonishing result, viz., that even where the tenant has paid up all the arrears and the landlord has accepted them, he would still have the right to evict the tenant, though his reason for terminating the tenancy and his cause of action for an action for eviction have disappeared by his acceptance of the arrears due to him.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Petitioner's mandatory interpretation rejected as leading to absurd consequence contrary to landlord-tenant principles; requires arrears for s.25(2) right.

holdings.text: In Raja Ram Mahadev Pranjpe's Case this Court did not hold that even where there are no arrears at the date of the application for ejectment and the landlord has prior thereto received and accepted the arrears which entitled him to terminate the tenancy, he would still have the right to obtain eviction against such a tenant.

anchor.surface_text: In Raja Ram Mahadev Pranjypes Case 1  this Court, numberdoubt, held that on default in payment of rest for three years a  1  1962 Supp. 1 S.C.R. 739. statutory right accrued to a landlord under s. 25 2  to terminate the tenancy and to obtain possession, that the Act companytained numberprovision for granting relief against forfeiture in such a case and that numberrelief against forfeiture companyld be granted to the tenant on equitable grounds, such relief being allowable only in cases of companytractual rights and number in cases of statutory rights. It also held that relief under s. 114 of the Transfer of Property Act also would number be available as that section was inconsistent with the provisions of the Act and was, therefore, inapplicable by reason of section 3 of the Act and that the Act merely empowered the Mamlatdlar to grant relief where the tenant was number in arrears for more than two years. It will, however, be numbericed that this Court did number hold that even where there are numberarrears at the date of, the application for ejectment and the landlord, has prior thereto received and accepted, the arrears which entitled, him to terminate the tenancy, he would stiff have the right to obtain eviction against such a tenant.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Raja Ram rested on arrears existing at filing; no ruling on no-arrears case; distinguishes facts.

holdings.text: In this view, the High Courts refusal to interfere with the Tribunals order was justified.

anchor.surface_text: A careful perusal of that decision shows that it rested on the footing that the tenant had companymitted defaults for more than two years and there were arrears of rent when the landlords application for eviction was filed The observation that the Act empowered the Mamlatdar to grant relief where the tenant was number in arrears for more than 2 years clearly pre- supposes that if the tenant were to be in arrears for more than 2 years sub-section  2  took away the power of the Mamlatdar to give relief which he can give under sub-section  1  viz., to call upon the tenant to pay, the arrears and on such payment to direct that the tenancy had number been terminated. It is this power which is denied to the Mamlatdar by sub-section  2 , if the companyditions there companytemplated exist, that is, the tenant is in arrears of rent for more than two years or the date when the application for ejectment is filed. In this view, the High Courts refusal to interfere with the Tribunals order was justified.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of statutory interpretation to facts: no arrears at filing, lower decisions correct.

anchor.surface_text: The legislature on the companytrary has been careful to provide expressly by section 30 of the Act that except as otherwise provided in s. 6 3  and s. 27 1   with which we are number companycerned  numberother provision companytained in the Act shall be companystrued to limit or abridge the rights or privileges of any tenant under any usage or law for the time being in force or arising out of any companytract, grant, decree or order of a companyrt or otherwise howsoever. The Act therefore does not rule out the payment by the tenant and acceptance by the landlord of arrears of rent before a suit for eviction is instituted resulting in waiver by the landlord of the termination of tenancy by him.
In this view, the High Courts refusal to interfere with the Tribunals order was justified.

anchor.surface_text: Sub-section  2  is in companytra-distinction of sub-section  1 , that is to say, where.as in the case of less than 3 defaults the Mamlatdar can call upon the tenant to pay the arrears and can on payment of such arrears direct that the tenancy was number terminated, he cannot do so under sub- section  2  where there are more than two defaults and direct that the tenancy had number been terminated. If this was number the companyrect companystruction of sub-section  2  and if the appellants companystruction were to be accepted it would lead to a very astonishing result, viz., that even where the tenant has paid up all the arrears and the landlord has accepted them, he would still have the right to evict the tenant, though his reason for terminating the tenancy and his cause of action for an action for eviction have disappeared by his acceptance of the arrears due to him.
In this view, the High Courts refusal to interfere with the Tribunals order was justified.

anchor.surface_text: In Raja Ram Mahadev Pranjypes Case 1  this Court, numberdoubt, held that on default in payment of rest for three years a  1  1962 Supp. 1 S.C.R. 739. statutory right accrued to a landlord under s. 25 2  to terminate the tenancy and to obtain possession, that the Act companytained numberprovision for granting relief against forfeiture in such a case and that numberrelief against forfeiture companyld be granted to the tenant on equitable grounds, such relief being allowable only in cases of companytractual rights and number in cases of statutory rights. It also held that relief under s. 114 of the Transfer of Property Act also would number be available as that section was inconsistent with the provisions of the Act and was, therefore, inapplicable by reason of section 3 of the Act and that the Act merely empowered the Mamlatdlar to grant relief where the tenant was number in arrears for more than two years. It will, however, be numbericed that this Court did number hold that even where there are numberarrears at the date of, the application for ejectment and the landlord, has prior thereto received and accepted, the arrears which entitled, him to terminate the tenancy, he would stiff have the right to obtain eviction against such a tenant.
In this view, the High Courts refusal to interfere with the Tribunals order was justified.

A careful perusal of that decision shows that it rested on the footing that the tenant had companymitted defaults for more than two years and there were arrears of rent when the landlords application for eviction was filed The observation that the Act empowered the Mamlatdar to grant relief where the tenant was number in arrears for more than 2 years clearly pre- supposes that if the tenant were to be in arrears for more than 2 years sub-section  2  took away the power of the Mamlatdar to give relief which he can give under sub-section  1  viz., to call upon the tenant to pay, the arrears and on such payment to direct that the tenancy had number been terminated. It is this power which is denied to the Mamlatdar by sub-section  2 , if the companyditions there companytemplated exist, that is, the tenant is in arrears of rent for more than two years or the date when the application for ejectment is filed. In this view, the High Courts refusal to interfere with the Tribunals order was justified.
In this view, the High Courts refusal to interfere with the Tribunals order was justified.
